contextId.information: James is using rhetorical questions to teach and possibly scold his readers. AT: "You are making judgments among yourselves and becoming judges with evil thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: are you not judging among yourselves? Have you not become judges with evil thoughts?

contextId.information: Here James uses a rhetorical question to teach his readers not to show favoritism. It can be made a statement. AT: "God has chosen ... love him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: did not God choose ... love him?

contextId.information: Here James uses a rhetorical question to correct his readers. AT: "It is the rich people who oppress you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
contextId.quote: Is it not the rich who oppress you?

contextId.information: Here James uses a rhetorical question to correct and teach his readers. It can be made a statement. AT: "The rich people ... belong to." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

James is using a rhetorical question to teach his audience. AT: "It is no good at all, fellow believers, if someone says he has faith, but he has no works." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What good is it, my brothers, if someone says he has faith, but if he has no works?

contextId.information: James uses a rhetorical question to teach his audience. AT: "that is not good." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
James poses this question to set up his next teaching. AT: "I will show you how, ... useless." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you want to know, ... useless?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question is used to rebut the foolish man's arguments from  [[:en:bible:notes:jas:02:18|2:18]], who refuses to believe that faith and works go together. AT: "Abraham our father was certainly justified" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Was not Abraham our father justified

contextId.information: James is using this rhetorical question to instruct his audience. AT: "it was what Rahab the prostitute did that justified her ... another road." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: was not Rahab the prostitute justified by works ... another road?

contextId.information: James uses a rhetorical question to remind believers about what happens in nature. This can be stated in active form. AT: "A spring does not pour out both fresh and bitter water." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Does a spring pour out from its opening both sweet and bitter water?

contextId.information: James uses two more rhetorical questions to remind the believers about what happens in nature. AT: "A fig tree cannot grow olives, my brothers, nor can a grapevine grow figs." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Does a fig tree, my brothers, make olives? Or a grapevine, figs?

contextId.information: James uses this question to teach his audience about proper behavior. The words "wise" and "understanding" are similar. AT: "I will tell you how a wise and understanding person is to act." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
contextId.quote: Who is wise and understanding among you?

contextId.information: James uses this question to rebuke his audience. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "It is because you have evil desires" or "It is because you desire evil things"  â€‹(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do they not come from your desires that fight

contextId.information: James uses this question to correct his audience. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "No one knows what will happen tomorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who knows what will happen tomorrow

contextId.information: "If anyone is enduring troubles, he should pray" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is anyone among you suffering hardship? Let him pray

contextId.information: "If anyone is sick, he should call" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is anyone among you sick? Let him call
